I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  Mongolia  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for 
technical assistance (TA) to help develop a strategy to guide the Government’s and the ADB’s 
future cooperation and joint programs in the urban development and housing sector. This TA is 
included  in  the  Mongolia  Country  Strategy  and  Program  Update  for  2004–2006,1  and  is 
programmed  for  2004.2  Fact-finding  for  the  TA  was  undertaken  in  April–May  2004  and 
agreement was reached with the Government on the goals, purpose, scope, implementation 
arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference  for  the  TA.  The  TA 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Mongolia experienced rapid urbanization in the second half of the 20th century and this 
trend  was  accelerated  during  the  transition  from  a  centrally  planned  to  a  market-based 
economy. By 2000, the urban population was 1.4 million, equivalent to 58% of the national 
population of 2.4 million. More than half of the urban population live in Ulaanbaatar, while 10% 
live in Darhan and Erdenet. The remaining 40% live in 18 provincial (aimag) capitals with 
average populations of 22,000.3 Provincial capitals function primarily as the administrative and 
service centers for rural population with densities varying widely but averaging less than one 
person per square kilometer and spread over an area half the size of India. Each province is 
divided into about 20 districts (soums), which are further subdivided into 4–6 bags (the smallest 
administrative unit), with 50 to 100 families in each. There are currently 340 urban and rural 
districts and 1,634 bags. 
 
3.  Under socialist planning, apartment areas were separated from ger (traditional tent) 
areas, and this is still sustained in every urban area in Mongolia. The apartment areas are 
served by electricity; piped and hot water; sewerage; central heating; solid waste collection; and 
a  full  range  of  education,  health,  social,  and  commercial  facilities.  However,  services  are 
minimal in the ger areas, which are characterized by individual fenced plots with gers and/or 
small shelters. Water tankers supply neighborhood water kiosks; sanitation facilities are on-plot 
pit  latrines;  and  coal,  wood,  or  dung-fired  stoves  are  used  for  heating  and  cooking.  The 
separation of the two areas has contributed to the development of urban areas with extensive 
unused open space and low densities, making service delivery more costly. This is especially so 
for the ger areas, which are on the urban periphery in most cities and towns. Thus, households 
in the ger areas pay significantly more for heating, water, and solid waste disposal than those in 
apartment areas. Since water in ger areas costs up to 20 times as much per liter as water 
supplied to apartment residents, water consumption in the ger areas is low, typically 6–12 liters 
per capita per day.4 Over half the population of Ulaanbaatar and at least half of the population of 
the provincial capitals live in the ger areas. 
 
4.  Urban infrastructure and services are seriously dilapidated and in urgent need of repair 
and improvement. Mongolia had developed basic infrastructure and services in urban areas with 
financial assistance from the former Soviet Union. The program stopped when the former Soviet 
Union collapsed. Many urban areas ended up with incompletely installed infrastructure and 
services. At the end of 2000, 40% of the urban population had access to piped water, 39% to

5.  About 35% of the national population are poor, living below a weighted national poverty 
line of about $17 per person per month, half the international norm of $1 per day. People living 
in Ulaanbaatar are marginally poorer (34% fall below the poverty line) than those living in rural 
areas (33% below the poverty line). However, those living in provincial capitals are the poorest, 
with 45% below poverty line. At the same time, the average monthly income of households 
living in the ger areas is less than 70% of that of households living in the apartment areas.5 The 
poverty reduction programs and measurement should be targeted at the ger areas, and the 
imbalances in the provision of infrastructure and services between the apartment areas and the 
ger areas need to be redressed. 
 
6.  The parliament of Mongolia approved the Regional Development Concept (RDC) in June 
2001 (Resolution No. 57). The objectives of the RDC are to (i) create a favorable environment 
for narrowing the disparities in urban and rural development within regions; (ii) accelerate 
economic growth; and (iii) support social progress through utilization of natural, agricultural, and 
crop-originated resources in line with the capabilities of the particular regions, leading to the 
decentralization of population concentration. Based on the RDC, eight pillar centers6 were 
identified as regional administrative centers and development nodes. About MNT500 million 
was allocated to develop a general plan for each of the pillar centers. The general plan will 
comprise (i) plans for the background, structure, functions, and optimal size of the pillar center; 
and (ii) drawing plans for engineering, construction, territorial, and land specifications. The plans 
are to be completed by July 2004. 
 
7.  ADB has assisted the urban development and housing sector through loan and grant 
projects  for  basic  urban  services  improvements  in  the  provincial  capitals,  housing  sector 
finance,  living  environment  improvement  in  the  ger  areas,  cadastral  survey  and  land 
registration, and a TA project on regional development planning.7 ADB has been one of the 
main sources of external assistance for the sector. The World Bank has recently approved the 
Second Ulaanbaatar Services Improvement Project. The objective of the project is to improve 
the quality of life of the urban poor in the ger areas of Ulaanbaatar by providing basic urban 
services—water supply, sanitation, drainage, laundry and bath houses, and access roads and 
pathways—in a sustainable manner. The World Bank, in cooperation with the City Alliance, is 
also developing the City Development Strategies in Darhan and Erdenet. The City Development 
Strategies  is  a  dynamic  process  that  facilitates  the  engagement  and  commitment  of  the 
communities and key stakeholders to define their problems and opportunities as a city, to

realization  of  their  strategy.  Among  other  agencies,  the  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency, United Nations Development Programme, and United States Agency for International 
Development are active in the sector. Ongoing external assistance to the urban development 
and  housing  sector  is  summarized  in  Appendix  2.  Major  interventions  are  focusing  on 
Ulaanbaatar, and assistance to other cities is limited in scale. The TA is needed to undertake 
comprehensive analysis on the urban development housing conditions of the country. 
 
8.  ADB’s urban sector profile for Mongolia was prepared in 1999. Given high rural-to-urban 
migration and rapid growth of Ulaanbaatar, the rapid growth of the urban informal economy, 
changes in investment and employment patterns, and revised Government priorities that are 
reflected in several new laws,8 ADB’s approach to the urban development and housing sector 
needs  revision.  The  TA  will  review  the  recent  developments,  review  priority  sectoral  and 
geographical needs and areas of focus, and identify future directions for ADB’s strategy and 
program in urban development and housing to maximize its impact on the sector. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The overall goal of the TA is to help increase understanding and capability to plan and 
implement ADB’s TA and lending programs for the urban development and housing sector in 
Mongolia for 2005–2008.9 The TA will serve to facilitate economic growth in urban areas while 
enhancing the access of the poor to urban services and sustaining the environment. 
 
10.  The principal outputs will be (i) updated basic information in urban development and 
housing, (ii) an urban development and housing sector strategy for ADB for 2005–2008, and (iii) 
outline proposals of priority investments and institutional capacity development requirements. 
The process and approach of the TA are also expected to help the Government increase 
awareness of issues, constraints, and opportunities in the sector. The results of the TA will be 
fully incorporated in the country strategy and program for Mongolia, which is being prepared. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will use the available sector study results, and focus on identifying concrete 
measures  that  can  readily  be  implemented,  through  consultations  with  concerned  key 
government  officials  and  other  stakeholders.  Such  consultations  will  be  participated  in  by 
academic institutions, dwellers’ representatives, and civil society organizations. 
 
1.  Updated Basic Information in Urban Development and Housing 
12.  The TA will include a comprehensive assessment of the urban situation, covering (i) 
national population growth, rural-to-urban migration, and urbanization trends in the context of 
national economic trends; (ii) recent changes in economic conditions in urban areas; (iii) urban 
employment patterns and opportunities; (iv) the potential growth of industrial and commercial 
activities in urban areas; (v) social and economic linkage between rural and urban areas; (vi) 
spatial and environmental conditions, and urban settlement patterns; (vii) the condition of urban 
infrastructure including water supply, sanitation, heating and hot water supply, solid waste

management,  urban  roads,  and  public  transportation;  (viii)  land-use  patterns  and  housing 
conditions; (ix) urban poverty profile; (x) institutional relationship and responsibilities of the 
central and local government agencies; (xi) municipal finance and financing urban development;  
(xii) regulations, procedures, and requirements of urban planning; (xiii) existing standards and 
norms  related  to  urban  development  and  housing;  (xiv)  the  Government’s  policies  and 
investment plans; (xv) progress in planning and implementing of the activities proposed under 
the RDC; and (xvi) past, ongoing, and planned external assistance by other funding agencies in 
urban development and housing. Past and ongoing ADB loans and TAs in urban development 
and housing (footnote 7) will also be reviewed and specific lessons learned will be drawn.  
 
13.  Based on the assessments, key sector issues and problems as well as opportunities for 
development will be determined and analyzed. Constraints to efficient urban service delivery 
due to very low population density, severe pressure on urban infrastructure caused by heavy 
rural to urban migration, and difficulties in applying socialist planning systems and standards 
and norms inherited from the former Soviet Union to the current situation in Mongolia should be 
paid special attention. 
 
2.  Urban Development and Housing Sector Strategy 
14.  A framework will be developed providing clear directions for improving the institutional 
set-up  for  urban  development;  urban  planning,  management,  and  finance;  private  sector 
participation; poverty reduction; and environmental management. Future demands for urban 
infrastructure and services will be estimated on the basis of population projections for major 
urban centers and for the whole country. Based on the framework, an urban development and 
housing  sector  strategy  will  be  prepared.  The  strategy  will  guide  ADB’s  TA  and  lending 
programs  in  the  sector  for  2005–2008.  Priority  will  be  given  to  measures  to  reduce 
rural-to-urban migration, increase efficiency in urban services, maximize cities’ contribution to 
the national economic and social development, and improve living conditions in the ger areas in 
a cost-effective manner. 
 
3.  Outline Proposal of Priority Investments 
15.  Priority  areas  of  investments  will  be  identified  through  assessing  the  needs  and 
demands for urban infrastructure and services, and financial and institutional capabilities of the 
Government. Institutional capacity development requirements to realize such investments will 
also be examined. Geographic scope (Ulaanbaatar as the capital or pillar centers identified 
under the RDC or provincial capitals) and approach to be taken (integrated urban development 
or urban subsector development) will be identified for the priority investments. The TA will 
recommend  further  steps  for  feasibility  work  for  the  priority  investments,  including  project 
location, objectives and rationale, major subsector focus, expected outputs, possible funding 
sources, time frame, and appropriate implementation arrangements. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $420,000 equivalent, of which $300,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $120,000 equivalent the local currency cost. ADB will finance the 
entire foreign exchange cost and $50,000 equivalent in local currency cost, totaling $350,000 
equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The 
Government will fund the remaining $70,000 equivalent for office accommodation, utilities, local 
communications, administrative support, and counterpart staff. Equipment and materials to be

5
financed  by  the  TA  will  be  procured  by  the  consultants.10  Detailed  cost  estimates  and  a 
financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Ministry of Infrastructure will be the Executing Agency for the TA and will provide 
policy guidance, facilitate interagency coordination, and resolve any institutional problems. The 
Government Implementing Agency for Construction, Urban Development and Public Utilities will 
be the implementing Agency for the TA and will oversee the day-to-day implementation of the 
TA. It will appoint a senior officer as a TA manager, assisted by other qualified counterpart staff. 
 
18.  The TA will require 10 person-months of international and 9 person-months of domestic 
consulting services. The international consultants will include an urban development specialist 
and team leader (4 person-months), an urban infrastructure specialist (3 person-months), and a 
municipal and housing finance specialist (3 person-months). The domestic consultants will 
include urban governance and management specialist (4 person-months), a social development 
specialist (2 person-months), an environment  specialist (2 person-months), and a financial 
specialist (1 person-month). All consultants will be engaged through a firm in accordance with 
the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and 
other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. A biodata 
proposal will be used to recruit consultants and the quality- and cost-based selection method 
will be used for consultant selection. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix 4. 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 4 months, from August to December 2004. 
The major reports required from the consultants are (i) an inception report describing the 
detailed work program, by the end of the third week after the commencement of the TA; and (ii) 
a draft final report, within 3.5 months after the commencement of the TA. Tripartite meetings will 
be held with the Government, ADB, and the consultants to discuss the TA reports. A final report 
will be submitted 2 weeks after receiving comments from the Government and ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Mongolia  for  Developing  an  Urban  Development  and  Housing  Sector 
Strategy, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

B.  Domestic Consultants 
1.  Urban Governance and Management Specialist (4 person-months) 
4.  The consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  review the legal and organizational relationships between the central and local 
governments, including the legal status of local agencies responsible for urban 
service delivery and their relationships with provincial governments; 
 
(ii)  review key decision-making procedures, including those for budget and project 
approval, land-use planning, and development and building permission; 
 
(iii)  review the organization and human resources of local governments; identify key 
business  processes,  organizational  arrangements,  and  management  systems 
needing improvements; and prepare recommendations for their improvements; 
 
(iv)  identify institutional capacity building requirements for realization of the priority 
investments proposed under the strategy; and 
 
(v)  propose  appropriate  implementation  arrangements  for  the  proposed  priority 
investments. 
 
2.  Social Development Specialist (2 person-months) 
5.  The consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  assess participation of the poor, women, and nongovernment organizations in 
urban planning and service delivery; 
 
(ii)  assess the scale of urban poverty, including the number of urban poor, levels of 
household income, access to urban services, and specific needs of the poor; and 
assess urban poverty trends in Ulaanbaatar, pillar centers, and provincial capitals 
(differences between apartment areas and ger areas should be addressed); 
 
(iii)  identify future direction for urban poverty reduction; and 
 
(iv)  assist the team leader in preparing social development aspects of feasibility 
works of the priority investments.
